FacilityName: John Taylor Fertilizers, Inc. - Rio Linda

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
John Taylor Fertilizers-Rio Linda facility is located approximately 3.4 miles northeast of where the I-5, SR-99, and SR-70 freeways meet in Rio Linda, California.

The facility has developed a Risk Management Program to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785), and Environmental Protection Agency?s Risk Management Plan requirements (Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Chapter 1, Part 68).  The facility is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facility staff is highly trained and utilizes log sheets and employee rounds to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using anhydrous ammonia. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The facility has a long standing commitment to its workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system.  The facility?s policy is to implement reasonable standard operating procedures and maintenance tasks to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and used at the facility for blending into mixed grade fertilizers.  The anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored for use in the production of ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer.  The final product, ammonium polyphosphate, is no longer a regulated substance.  

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per CalARP/EPA RMP Program 2 Regulations one worst case analysis has been defined for the anhydrous ammonia system.  The meteorological conditions specifi

ed by Sacramento County and consistent with regulatory requirements for worst case scenarios were inputted into SLAB for the ammonia.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.  The worst case release scenarios are highly unlikely to occur because of active and passive mitigation measures that are available and used, and weather conditions that are unlikely as well.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: A more realistic alternative release scenario was modeled for the CalARP/EPA RMP Program 2 anhydrous ammonia.  The meteorological conditions specified by Sacramento County and consistent with regulatory requirements for alternative release scenarios were used.  SLAB was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The downwind distance for this alternative release scenario is significantly less than that for the worst case scenario.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook. 

Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the facility and facility personnel that make this worst case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).
In addition to the use of conserv

ative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with anhydrous ammonia:

?Process valves permit isolation of any leaks in place without exposing anyone to the anhydrous ammonia.
?The system utilizes automatic shut-downs that would prevent a deviation from resulting in a release.
?Entire area enclosed within containment wall to protect against vehicular impact.
?Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by plant personnel, as necessary.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
As part of the implementation of this CalARP/EPA RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  As ammonia is ?self alarming? due to its pungent odor, even minor releases are readily noticeable.
  
The Prevention Program 2 elements applied to the process include:
?Safety Information
?Hazard Review
?Operating Procedures
?Training
?Maintenance
?Compliance Audits
?Incident Investigation
?Emergency Response

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no CalARP/EPA RMP applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia at the facility in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility has an Emergency Action Plan filed with the Sacramento County Environmental Management Department and this plan includes:
?Reporting Procedures
?Evacuation Procedures
?Emergency Alarm Procedures
?Safety and Health Considerations
?Employee Alarm System
?Training
?Review of Emergency Action Plan
 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include the following: Hazard Review, Seismic Assessment, and Hazar
d Assessment.  Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will have been addressed by September 20, 2006.
